bug.short_desc: Property Dialog title does not handle some language strings correctly

long_desc.thetext:
So if you have a language such as simplified chinese the property dialog when it forms its title for the property dialog will grab your translated label for the element that properties is being shown on. However in the case of some languages such as simplified chinese the title is not formed correctly.
For example take a look at
PropertyDialog.java
in the CreateDialogOn() routine
there is code that does the following
------------------- //get your label info for the properties about to be shown on String name = getName(element); ... title = NLS.bind(WorkbenchMessages.PropertyDialog_propertyMessage, name); ------------------
The problem is that in the call NLS.Bind the combine string
WorkbenchMessages.PropertyDialog_propertyMessage
is in the simplified chinese case "{0} YYYY"
so you get
"XXX YYYY" (where X and Y are simplified chinese symbols)
which can be incorrect having a space, due to nature of the language.
Created an attachment (id=49740) Shows problem with space in simplified chinese
What if the name of the element is English? Should there still be a space in that case?

The way this works is the string is constructed from message.properties files. in english the string is grabbed from the english messages.properties file and is something like:
"Properties For {0}"
however in simplified chinese the string that is provided is
"{0} XXX"
so the fix needs to be in how the string building is handled and created when using localized strings. In the simplified chinese case a space is sometimes wrong.

I reread this and I think you are asking what if the user provided string is english but the message is Simplified chinese? In that case I believe a space is the right thing to do, however, I'm NOT very knowledgable on these things, you may need to talk to localization folks for the final answer on this.

I took a look at the zh translated .properties files and compared them to the strings in the English properties files - I found that sometimes the space is removed from some strings, and in other cases it is not. Kit, do you know why that is?
Note that if this problem is to be fixed, the only way would be in the zh translated .properties files, not in code, since the platform generally tries to avoid having code that is language-dependent.

In general, Chinese characters (both simplified and traditional) are concatenated together without spaces. I think when the translation verification tester sees what is being substituted into the the {0} variable during verification test, they may remove the space.
A few other languages have grammatical gender. To solve both the extra space problem in Chinese and grammatical gender problem during substitution for other languages, it's better NOT to use substitution if possible, when the value of the variable is limited to 2 or 3 choices. It's better to use separate strings for each value. Separate strings do not create too much extra work for translators.
As for this problem, you may move it to Platform/Releng and assign to me, kitlo@us.ibm.com. We will correct this in the next release.

Kit, I think in this case the substituted string could be either English or Chinese - if it were English, I believe having the space makes sense (correct me if I am wrong), but if it is Chinese then having the space does not make sense. This might be one of those strings where we just have to do what's best for most languages (leave the space). But I will leave that up to you and the translators.

You are right that if the substituted string is an English word (or numbers), then the extra space may be okay for Chinese.
Is it possible to provide a list of possible values for the string. That will help the translators to determine the best solution.
Thanks, Kit

The string (in English) is "Properties for X" where X is the selected element, so it could be an English word or a Chinese word. I think this is one of those cases where you don't know for certain what you are going to get because the element name could have a chinese name or an english name.
Created an attachment (id=70198) properties for {0}

I discussed this with the simplified chinese translator. If we remove the space in front of {0}, when Chinese chars are subsituted into {0}, the string looks good. When Engish is subsituted into {0}, it's still not too bad. We will go with this.
Created an attachment (id=70202) properties for {0} - revised

attachment.desc: Shows problem with space in simplified chinese

bug.short_desc: [Catalog] A child XML Catalog can not be added from the file system

long_desc.thetext: If one tries to add a "next XML catalog" and the URI specified is encoded (i.e. blank spaces replaced with "%20") the catalog cannot be added and a "resource cannot be located" error appears.

Created an attachment (id=49666) Patch
This patch adds a URI decoder that makes it possible to resolve encoded URIs.
Craig, could you take a look at this patch?
Created an attachment (id=50197) Patch
(From update of attachment 49666) I believe the 2nd patch obsoletes this one.
Thanks for the patch Gabriel. It's likely too late to get this fix into WTP 1.5.1 so I've targetted this for WTP 1.5.2.

Detailed description of the problem:
When adding a "Next Catalog", if the user selects to browse the file system, the resulting file name will be an encoded file URI. For example, if the user selects the file "C:\Documents and Settings\User\NextCatalog.xml", the entry for the catalog that appears on the dialog box will be "file:///C:/Documents%20and%Settings/User/NextCatalog.xml". The problem happens inmediately after selecting the file: an error message will appear indicating that the resource cannot be located. In addition to this, the "OK" button of the dialog box will be disabled given that the entry is considered erroneous. In other words, new catalogs cannot be added if their location is obtained using the file system browse button (or if the user inputs the resource location manually in encoded file URI format).
The problem happens because of the file URI encoding, if removed (replacing the %20 by spaces in this example) the error message will dissapear and the "OK" button of the dialog box will become enabled.
This patch solves this problem by making it possible to properly locate encoded file URI recources. So when the user selects the next catalog by browsing the file system, the new entry is properly resolved and no error messages appear, the "OK" button in the dialog box is accordinly kept enabled so the catalog can be added.
Another problem this patch fixes is the case where relative URIs appear in a catalog file. While these are not currently supported (although a patch to support them has already been written: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=126641) the problem here consists in not properly adding and resolving the catalog entries if one or more relative URIs are present. To reproduce this problem: add a "next catalog" file that contains relative and absolute URIs, then try to expand these on the XML catalogue preference dialog box: the entries of the catalog are missing.
This patch solves the problem: when a "next catalog" is added, all entries are properly dislpayed in the preferences dialog box and correctly resolved (those with relative URIs will appear with a red cross given that they are not currently supported).

Thanks for the clarification Gabriel. When I originally read this bug I thought it just concerned a spurious error indicator ... but it sounds like this problem is actually stopping the user from pushing OK in the dialog and breaking the 'next catalog' funtion.
I'd like to put this fix forward for PMC consideration.
Background ---------- The XML Catalog UI allows users to add entries to delegate to one or more XML Catalogs that they may have on their file system (using the 'nextCatalog' feature of the XML Catalog spec). Often users have XML Catalogs that they wish to manage via source control or that come canned with their operating system (some Unix systems come with pre-canned XML Catalogs) etc. The XML Catalog UI allows users to browse their file system and select the catalog and add it as a child or delegate to the 'global' XML Catalog in the WTP preferences.
Problem ---------- The dialog that allows a user to add a delegate XML Catalog won't allow the user to proceed if the catalog comes from a file system directory with spaces in the name or strange characters that aren't valid URI characters. The user will see an error message saying the file can't be found and the dialog's 'OK' button will be disabled.
Solution ---------- The selected file system path (for the delegate xml catalog) must be encoded correctly as a valid URI and then decoded correctly before we go off to check the file system to see if the file exists. The encode/decode logic already exists in the URI class. Gabriel's change involves adding a few lines of code to ensure the URI is decode correctly into a file system path so that the file existence check will succeed.
FYI, we use java.io.File for the existence check instead of URI.openStream() for performance reasons. We found the Catalog UI to be quite unresponsive when it was doing URI.openStream() for resources are 99.9% of the time are files on the file system.
Risk ---------- This is a very small isolated change with low risk. Gabriel has done a good deal of testing to ensure that this change fixes the known problem without any unwanted side effects.
+1 While we developers know better than to use file names with spaces in them :) my previous experience tells me casual users are not so careful ... so, I think worth fixing.

+1
space :-) the final frontier
Patch released to 1.5.1 and HEAD.
Closing as resolved since 1.5.1. If this bug should not be closed, please reopen.

bug.short_desc: various parts - XmiWriter, XTend

long_desc.thetext:
Assume you are using a M2M transformation in order to generate a model file, e.g. a meta model. As for example in uml2ecore, where I use an M2M to create a ecore file from a uml2 model.
Now consider, you have a project structure as follows: * theProject * src workflow.oaw * src-gen
Assume you want to write the generated .ecore file into the src-gen folder, so that the file will be on the classpath for subsequent work. So, the file you write using the XMIWriter; you specify the file to be called src-gen/something.ecore
Now, the problem is that the 'src-gen' will be part of some internal referneces in the ecore file. However, if you use it, since src-gen is part of the classpath, the file cannot be opened/used, since src-gen is wrong.
A solution for this problem is probably to distinguish between a base path and a file name in the XMIWriter.
TOBEFIXEDIN411
TOBEFIXEDIN411
FIXED.

bug.short_desc: PM: Plan Iteration task should have greater stakeholder involvement

long_desc.thetext: SHouldn't the stakeholders be actively involved in setting the iteration objectives, and perhaps even the plan?

I changed 1st and 2nd steps to articulate the role of stakeholder. Is this enough?
Define the iteration objectives At the beginning of an iteration, the Role: Project Manager works with the team to define 1-5 objectives. These objectives should be a refinement of the iteration objectives found in the Artifact: pm_iteration_plan, and should provide high-level direction to what should be targeted for the iteration. The objectives should be driven based on Role: Stakeholder priorities, and will be revised as the iteration plan is finalized. The objectives are usually defined as high-level capabilities or scenarios that need to be implemented and tested during the iteration.
Produce detailed plan The Role: Project Manager works with the rest of the team, and especially the project stakeholders, to identify the high-priority work items from the Artifact: Work Items List to be addressed within the iteration. The high-level objectives provide guidance on what work items should be considered. The team should break down work items so they fit within the iteration as necessary. Actual effort to complete each Work Item should be estimated. When a team has decided to take on a Work Item, it will assign the work to one or several team members. Ideally, this is done by team members signing up to do the work, since this makes people motivated and committed to doing the job, but based on culture, you may instead have the project manager assign the work.
Define evaluation criteria Each iteration should include testing as a part of the evaluation, and the test objectives and test cases needs to be detailed. Other evaluation criteria may include successful demonstrations to key stakeholders, or favorable usage by a small group of target users.

Per, I think the text is fine.
Two minor fixes though: - 1st step: Artifact: pm_iteration_plan is a wrong link. It should be poiting to the base element, not the contributor. - Typo on 3rd step: ...test cases need to be detailed (not needs).
Ricardo.
Updated based on Ricardo's comments.

I reviewed version 1.11 in CVS - there are a few typos that will get fixed during proof reading but the intent to add greater stakeholder involvement has been adequately addressed - I recommend that we close this bug.
Closed per Kurt's recommendation.

bug.short_desc: [CopyPaste] Improvements to CopyingResource

long_desc.thetext:
These improvements to the CopyingResource class were suggested in bug 155548 but require API change, or will force changes in existing client code. Recording them here for consideration in 2.0.
1. The getHREF(Resource, EObject) method appends a fragment query. This is not necessary, given that GMFResource doesn't do it. Note that we append the fragment query to support historical resources and that if we remove the code, clients that work with such historical resources will have to subclass and override to add the support they need for themselves.
2. All references to "msl" terminology should be removed. Note that #getMslCopyingResourceSet and the mslCopyingResourceSet instance variable may be redundant since ResourceImpl already has a resourceSet instance variable.
3. Fields and query methods (like getResourcesMap(), isInResource(EObject)) should be made protected so that they can be called by subclasses.
Moving to the next release, GMF 2.1.

bug.short_desc: Contributing a Checklist to a Checklist Displays Link to Self in Publish Process

long_desc.thetext: When you Contribute a checklist to a checklist, the main checklist has a "More Information" section that links to the contributing checklist. This link becomes a link to itself after the page is published. Usually the "More Information" section contains links to guidelines the checklist would specifically link to.

This is a screenshot of the published checklist in the Browsing perspective. It correctly combines the two checklists, but not the Design link at the bottom. This is just a link to itself.
please comment whether this is the expected behaviour or a bug? There may be no previous spec on how to handle this situation.
bug in xsl/xml binding for checklist. fixed.
Fix is verified on buid RC1 0915.
v,closed.

bug.short_desc: Clearing of Graph root edit parts on configuration is incorrect.

long_desc.thetext: The Root edit parts of the graph viewers shouldn't be entirely unregistered and replaced when the viewer is configured. Rather, all child edit parts should be cleared. This will allow the layers, zoom managers, etc., to remain when new contents are created.

Created an attachment (id=49774) Patch
This patch takes care of 3 issues: 1. This bug: - All viewer impls now override the createDefaultRoot() method, and don't recreate the root edit part each time the contents are reset. Instead, the child edit parts are removed, and the edit parts are regenerated from the same root edit part. This allows for all of the same layers, viewports, zoom managers, etc., to be used. - All root edit parts now extend GraphRootEditPart, which takes care of all clean-up.
2. Bug #15480: -A new content provider: IGraphEntityRelationshipContentProvider, and related factories have been created. This allows for a more complete node-based model. Using this content provider, users can implement both IEntityStyleProvider, and IConnectionStyleProvider to style both nodes and relationships. -Possibly, the bug should remain open in case any other content providers can be thought of.
3. Bug #156286: -Rudementary top-level zoom support has been added to all implementations of graph viewers. Zooming can be done through the supplied ZoomIn/OutAction and ZoomContributionViewItem. -Should investigate fuller zoom support. Eg: zooming in by arbitrary values, and on arbitrary rectangles.
Patch is in head.
Fixed in the patch.
The bug referenced above should be #154580, not 15480.

bug.short_desc: The new AC fails to launch java agents on linux

long_desc.thetext:
Steps I took.
1. unzip archive agntctrl.linux_ia32-TPTP-4.2.0.2.zip 2. from bin directory ran ./SetConfig.sh - accepted defaults 3. edited agents/org.eclipse.tptp.TimeColector/agent.xml as described in the readme.txt 3. edited agents/org.eclipse.tptp.JavaTimeCollector/agent.xml set the executable to point to my installation of java set the classpath parameter to point to my installation of tptpcore.jar (org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution_4.2.0.v200606140100/tptpcore.jar) see below. Note the first Parameter uses the position="replace" option. This was needed otherwise the java execution failed with "Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:" This is another bug - however using position="replace" was is a workaround.
4. started the server with ./ACServer 5. Ran ./SampleClient to check it worked - it did. 6. From within the eclipse SDK, ran org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.samples.SampleClientAC.java. to check that it worked. This is a java client talking to a c++ agent. It worked. 7. Modified SampleClientAC.java to talk to JavaTimeCollector instead of TimeCollector 8. Ran SampleClientAC and the ./ACServer reports an exception. see below
My investigations into the exeception have found... 1. freeEnvironmentStrings is declared in libprocessControlUtil.so.4.2.0 2. libtptpConfig.so.4.2.0 has an undefined reference to it 3. libtptpConfig or libjavaBaseAgent should be linked against libprocessControlUtil to resolve this.
==== ACServer output ====== ./ACServer java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /space/geoff/downloads/eclipse/3.2/agntctrl/lib/libjavaBaseAgent.so.4.2.0: /space/geoff/downloads/eclipse/3.2/agntctrl/lib/libtptpConfig.so.4: undefined symbol: freeEnvironmentStrings at java.lang.ClassLoader$NativeLibrary.load(Native Method) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary0(ClassLoader.java:1586) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(ClassLoader.java:1511) at java.lang.Runtime.loadLibrary0(Runtime.java:788) at java.lang.System.loadLibrary(System.java:834) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.datacollection.BaseAgent.<clinit>(BaseAgent.java:98) org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.exceptions.NativeLibraryNotFound: Error: The native library not found. at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.datacollection.BaseAgent.init(BaseAgent.java:161) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.samples.TPTPJavaAgent.<init>(TPTPJavaAgent.java:54) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.samples.TPTPJavaAgent.main(TPTPJavaAgent.java:63) Exception in thread "main" java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: register0 at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.datacollection.BaseAgent.register0(Native Method) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.datacollection.BaseAgent.register(BaseAgent.java:202) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.samples.TPTPJavaAgent.main(TPTPJavaAgent.java:68)
=== modified agent.xml === <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> <!-- The Java Time Collector will work with the following ServiceConfig settings. (Bugzilla# 115006) a) The TransportLayer namedPipeTL element that contains the named pipe name in the PipeName element must be set to "ramaster". b) The TransportLayer sharedMemTL element that contains the shared mem buffer name in the element MemName must be set to "rabuffer" --> <Agent Name="org.eclipse.tptp.JavaTimeCollector"> <Interface>org.eclipse.tptp.agent</Interface> <Interface>org.eclipse.tptp.collector</Interface> <SingleInstance>0</SingleInstance> <Bound>0</Bound> <MaxControllers>-1</MaxControllers> <MaxObservers>-1</MaxObservers> <ConfigFile>c:\tptp\agents\org.eclipse.tptp.JavaTimeCollector\config\agentconfig.xml</ConfigFile> <LaunchConfiguration> <launchInfo> <Application executable="java" path="%JAVA_PATH%"> <Parameter position="replace" value="-Djava.library.path=/space/geoff/downloads/eclipse/3.2/agntctrl/lib" /> <Parameter value="-classpath" /> <Parameter value="/space/geoff/downloads/eclipse/3.2/extensions/tptp-4.2.0.2-200608021100/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution_4.2.0.v200606140100/tptpcore.jar" /> <Parameter value="org.eclipse.tptp.platform.execution.samples.TPTPJavaAgent"/> </Application> </launchInfo> </LaunchConfiguration> </Agent>

the following change makes it work for me.
================= --- AgentBase.make 2006-09-08 12:25:39.000000000 +1000 +++ AgentBase.make.new 2006-09-08 12:25:19.000000000 +1000 @@ -43,7 +43,7 @@ # list of additional libraries to be linked with # (separated by blanks) #----------------------------------- -LIBS := uuid dl transportSupport tptpUtils tptpLogUtils tptpConfig pthread xerces-c +LIBS := uuid dl transportSupport tptpUtils tptpLogUtils tptpConfig processControlUtil pthread xerces-c
#----------------------------------- # list of additional library directories to search from

Guru, The tptpConfig-should-link-in-processControlUtil problem should be assigned to me... I just checked and we put this in on Windows but not on Linux. I can fix that.
But I'm not sure that this is a single bug... is the "replace" stuff a separate bug? That's not mine... but the linking is... so if there is another bug you need to break it out prior to assigning to me.
The fix is a simple one will attach it. The code will be part of Head-CVS in 4.4

This is in

bug.short_desc: [search] find reference in workspace inconsistency

long_desc.thetext:
I've tried to find if this bug is already reported, but there are so many bugs related to java search that I file a new one :-)
My problem is that when I select a method declaration in a class, I click the search button and run the default search proposed Eclipse doesn't find all my references. It seems that it only finds references in projects having a project dependency on the project in which the method is declared.
Now if I go in one other project in which this method is referenced, but with no project dependency, the class being available in a jar in the classpath of the project (not found by the first search), then I select the method referenced in a java source file, click the search button. The first thing I notice is that it isn't filled exactly in the same way as before: the method signature in the dialog text field has fully qualified names for parameters, while they were simple names in my previous attempt. Then if I perform the search Eclipse finds a lot more reference (maybe all, can't know for sure).
What is even stranger is that even if I select again the method declaration in my other project, clieck the search button, select the method with fully qualified names for parameters in combo box, and perform the search, it still doesn't find my references! So it seems that in some way the search dialog is (badly) related to the current selection or opened java source file.
Note that I experienced the same problem with eclipse 3.2. Another thing which might have a relationship to the problem is that my jar dependencies are in a classpath container (IvyDE).
If any one has a workaround or a patch, it would really be welcome!

If I understood right, this is your scenario
project1 myjar.jar com.x.y.A
project2 src com.x.y.A.java
project3 depends on project2
Note that the two 'A' are not the same. Search will correctly resolve the classpath and find out which of them is really resolved by a reference.
Reopen if I understood wrong.

I'm not sure if I should reopen or not, because I think you understood correctly, but I still think there is something wrong, at least in the dialog. Imagine that I open the dialog wit no opened editor, and type in a method signature from class A, and ask to search for all references in workspace. It will find the references (if I take your example) in both project 1 and project 3.
Now if I open the class A source code, select the method name, open the same dialog, it is prefilled with the method signature. Great! It looks exactly the same as the one I filled by hand before. Nevertheless if I perform the search the result won't be the same. Even more annoying, if I modify the method signature (I think even adding a space somewhere is enough), perform the search, and it will find all references including the one in project 1. From a user point of view, this really smells like a bug, because we have no hint of what is done under the cover.
So even if you think that it should only find references in project 3 when I select the method from its source before searching, giving some hint about it would be cool. Even better, why not disable the text field when you open the dialog while a java element is selected, with a checkbox (checked by default in this case) saying "search selected element only". Then if you uncheck the checkbox, you could modify the text field or not, and it would perform the same search as in my first use case.
This is really easy to do, I can submit a patch if you want, and it would improve the user experience with the powerful search feature.
What do you think?

bug.short_desc: [console] Console view does not display UTF-8 encoded strings, but JDT views do, e.g., the "Variables" view

long_desc.thetext:
Hi,
The JDT's "Variables" view is able to show UTF-8 encoded strings, but the "Console" view cannot.
Please see the images. The "Console" view's content is from the Java statement 'System.out.println(utf8Str);', where 'utf8Str' is the UTF-8 encoded string as displayed in the "Variables" view.
Created an attachment (id=49672) image file
Is the system's default encoding UTF8? If not you need to set the console encoding on the launch configruation's Common tab.
(As well, you'd need to add the vm argument -Dfile.encoding=UTF8 to the launch)

Ok, I did what Darin suggested. A bit better...But the console does not display correctly, the square characters at the end the '?' characters displayed in the midst of the Chinese phrase. The "Variables" view displays it correctly.
Created an attachment (id=49753) Image shows "Console" UTF-8 output not quite correct.

Is the console using the proper unicode font? you can set the console font in the preferences "General > Appearance > Colors and Fonts". Then look under "Debug > Console" in the tree.
Can you provide us with the test case for this. I.e. a simple program with the variable and UTF8 string?

Using -Dfile.ecoding=UTF-8 as a VM arg, and setting the console encoding to UTF-8 works for me when I use the Courier Thai font (will attach screen shot). The variables view tree does not display correctly, but we already have a bug for that (bug 183525).

Created an attachment (id=65429) screen shot
shows UTF8 output on console, with var view missing chars in the tree.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 183525 ***

attachment.desc: Image shows "Console" UTF-8 output not quite correct.

bug.short_desc: wrong highlighted current debugger line after line insertion while debug session

long_desc.thetext: when running debug session and inserting one or more lines, the current line highlighting appears by THE amount of inserted lines higher/above than the real current line until next loop iteration for example (or new function is executed)->until jump? With other words, the highlight is not adapted to sourcecode change while debugging, as it seems to me. This may happen with deleting lines, too, I guess (didn't test it)
When the lines are inserted, did you save and build to cause a hot swap on the VM being debugged? Was auto-build on?

The instruction pointer is updated to stay with the line of source code that it was referring to, as you edit your source (as any other editor annotations are). The IP is updated when you save your code and invoke hot swap. This is a transient state, and there is no way to know where your IP will end up until the save/hotswap is performed.

bug.short_desc: Need local client/agent communication solution for new AC API

long_desc.thetext: Requiring user to launch a separate process (the AC) on the local machine when they want to use an agent locally is not user friendly. The IAC was developed to solve this problem - it implements the RAC's API. Need a solution that implements the new tech AC's API. A solution that does not carry much AC baggage nor require JNI is desirable, want to keep the memory footprint small.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 141336 ***

bug.short_desc: org.eclipse.core.commands example does not work

long_desc.thetext: Paul is currently working on Commands.

This is correct, AFAIK. org.eclipse.core.commands is for providing command infrastructure. If you write a JFace only app, you could instantiate your own CommandManager singleton for use. Anybody can use it.
org.eclipse.core.commands is used by the workbench, not the other way around.
The workbench provides services like ICommandService ... the workbench documentation should be written in terms of ICommandService. If the workbench mentions CommandManager out of context, that needs to be fixed.
PW

Plugin or RCP developers need to use the workbench's ICommandService, not their own CommandManager. The documentation of both classes should indicate this.
The CommandManager documentation is lacking because it makes no mention of the singleton property of the CommandManager. Even if you don't create your own CommandManager instead of using the one in the workbench, you must use it as a singleton if you want it to work properly. The documentation should explain this.
The primary problem, as I see it, is that there is no documentation explaining how to do what I am trying to do: In an RCP application, associate an accelerator key with a button in a view. (For various reasons, I didn't want to create an Action to do this, perhaps that was my first mistake...) This seems like a fairly common task to me, and not only is there no documentation specifically for this task, but the documentation for related tasks makes no mention whatsoever of ICommandService. It does, however, mention Commands quite frequently; which leads to the org.eclipse.core.commands package documentation; which leads to futile attempts to instantiate your own CommandManager.

Information on using keybindings in eclipse is included in the Help>Help Contents>Plug-in Developer Guide>Advance Workbench Concepts
http://help.eclipse.org/help32/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/wrkAdv_keyBindings.htm
If you mean associate a keybinding with an arbitrary SWT button, it would only be because the button selection listener executed the same command that a keybinding does.
PW

Yes. However, in order to make that work, I need to get the Command object in order to make the button execute it. And in order to get the Command object, I need to use the ICommandService, which is not documented.
And, in actual practice, it is more convoluted still. Commands do not emit events indicating when they become enabled/disabled (at least as of 3.1). So, in order to properly enable/disable the button, it needs to work with the handler directly, since the handler DOES emit an enable/disable event. And, since Command does not have a getHandler() method, I am forced to create my own handler, call Command.setHandler() and just assume that no one else changes the handler later. At least, I assume that this is the way it needs to be done, since none of it is documented...

The documentation of commands, handlers, and services is the providance of the workbench (not the basic core.commands). But you are correct in that there is a lack of documentation, and what is available is spread between the Advanced Workbench Concepts and the extension points themselves (org.eclipse.ui.commands, org.eclipse.ui.handlers).
Check out Section 2 - Current Framework on http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Platform_UI_Command_Design, where we've been capturing behaviour.
PW

In 3.3 the Platform Plug-in Developers Guide was updated with descriptions of the org.eclipse.ui.examples.contributions plugin, which is implemented with commands/handlers/keybindings and menu contributions. PW

bug.short_desc: Slider without focus

long_desc.thetext: I'm trying to use my own Slider to represent a scrollbar in my widget because I wan't to change the position of the scrollbar. But the Slider takes focus (participates in tab traversal). This is not ideal. I would like to see Slider use SWT.NO_FOCUS or something similar.
Would excluding the slider from the tabbing order of its parent be an option? -> parentComposite.setTabList(...)
Well yes that is what I need. I shoulda thought of that. Thanks.
SWT.NO_FOCUS is a natural also for this one.

bug.short_desc: EPF not remembering the last publishing options and open library

long_desc.thetext: 1. Currently subset of the last publishing options are remembered, while others are not. Need to make them all been remembered consistently. 2. When users logoff windows or shutdown machines without exiting EPF properly, the last library opened and the last set of publishing options are not rememebered.

This has been fixed. For QA testing, please try three scenarios:
1. all cominations of the last selected publishing options should be remembered for the next publishing operation during the same session of running EPF. 2. The same is true when the application is exited and re-started 3. The same is true when the application is killed by system shutdown or user logoffs without exiting EPF first 4. The lats opened library should also be remembered as in the same situation as in #3.

verified on build epf-composer-1.0-RC1-N20060908-1910-win32 publishing options: destination directory and feedback URL are not remembered when the app is killed by system shutdown or user log offs without exiting epf first.

Can't reproduce this as I tried both loggoff and system shutdowm on Xp SP2. The only caveat is that only after the plublish is finished (Finish button is pressed), will the options been saved.
Please verify it again.
fixed, verified on build epf-composer-1.0-RC1-N20060908-1910-win32
V,R,&Closed.

A (real world) JET transformation with about 4000 templates results in a Java compiler error on the generated class org.eclipse.jet.compiled._jet_transformation. There is a method that results in more the maximum # of allows bytes of byte-code (~65K).
Investigate methods of reducing the size of these method (which grows linearly with the number of templates).

bug.short_desc: [Acceptance] Format does not take effect in pre-defined style report

long_desc.thetext:
Format does not take effect in pre-defined style report
Steps to reproduce: 1. New a report, add a sample datasource and data set with table "CUSTOMERS" 2. Drag the dataset in the report 3. Add a pre-define style "report" Set format Number as to Currency Set format Datetime to Shorttime Set format String to Lowercase 4. Preview the report in Web viewer, HTML and PDF
Expected result: Format takes effect
Actual result: Format does not take effect
The selector is not for the table or table slot, so getFactoryProperty need not search it. Render tasks should handle report selector for the formats.
Fixed.
Verified in build (200610090630), closed.

bug.short_desc: XML documents with empty xmlns and an unavailable schema are inacessible by normal XPath expressions

long_desc.thetext:
An XML document such as:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="Windows-31J"?> <app ejbProjectName="SampleProject" xmlns="http://org.eclipse.example/FOO" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://org.eclipse.example/FOO FooSchema.xsd"> <access type="jndi"> </access> </app>
where FooSchema.xsd is unavailable results in the following XPath expressions not working:
/app /app/access
The only work-around is to remove the xmlns, and xsi attributes.
XPath name match steps that include only an NCName (such as app or access, as above) should match nodes with identical unqualified names.
Changes committed to CVS.
Fixed in build 0.7.1 M200609072347

bug.short_desc: Unrecognized tokens in XPath expressions can be ignored

long_desc.thetext:
The XPath parser will silently ignore the rest of an XPath expression if it finds an unexpected token and the expression to that point is a valid expression.
For example, the expression
. [@foo = 'bar']
is not valid XPath (predicates are not allowed after .)
But, the XPath parser issues not error, and silently treats the expression as:
.
The parser should raise an error in such situations.
Changes committed to CVS.
Fixed in build 0.7.1 M200609072347

bug.short_desc: HttpService.registerServlet() method

long_desc.thetext:
I registered a servlet using the function registerServlet() provided by HttpService.
The mapping is like this http.registerServlet("/*.car", servlet, props, context);
where the string "/*.car" -> servlet alias servlet -> servlet instance
In this case the servlet is only invoked if the browser URL is http://localhost/*.car
In case of WEB.xml.If the same mapping is done.Then the servlet can be invoked using any of the URL mappings http://localhost/one.car http://localhost/kk.car http://localhost/hai.car
Why is this discrepancy ?

The OSGi HttpService unfortunately does not provide support for wildcards. The discrepancy is that the OSGi HttpService is not a mapping of the complete Servlet API. We'll see, but maybe the next revision might provide support.
If you're willing to look at a specific implementation there's a degree of support provided in HttpServices based on org.eclipse.equinox.servlet.bridge.http. It was added to provide support for JSP wildcarding however it should do what you want. See bug 140430

bug.short_desc: Set log priority to debug in SDK

long_desc.thetext: Nick, can you please try to modify the log4j.xml in the SDK zip as you do it for the tests? Maybe it's even better if we check-in the debug priority and only replace it to info in the runtime zip. Then we don't need to do it twice and, more important, I don't need to change it locally when I'm developing. That would also prevent me from accidentally committing this local tweak from time to time ;-)
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 156245 ***

Nick, I don't think, this one is a duplicate. I admit that it's similar and I might have better explained it ;-( The other bug is only about changing log level while the tests are running. The downloadable zips for runtime and sdk have still info level.
The matter is the following: Log level in CVS was debug and some users complained about large logs in production by default. So I changed the log level in CVS to info.
That led to problems with a) the too small test logs plus b) that I always have to remember not to commit my different development options plus c) most people start with installing the sdk (or checkout from CVS)and when they run into trouble we have no clue what happened.
Now I think, it's better to check in the debug log level into CVS. But then we need to automatically change it back to info *only in the runtime zip*.
Sorry for the confusion and the doubled work. It was my fault not to see the best solution right at the beginning. My suggestion:
1) I change log4j.xml in CVS (right now) 2) You remove the replace operation from the test installation (now it is already debug level) 3) You modify the build script to lift the log level from debug to info when the runtime zip is made out of the sdk zip
Btw. will you come with Ed to Germany in October? Would be nice to meet you and I had the chance to pay back for all your effort in form of delicious drinks ;-)

Have a look at /org.eclipse.emft/releng/cdo/builder/tests/scripts/log4j-priority.xml. This is hooked up in /org.eclipse.emft/releng/cdo/builder/tests/scripts/test.xml. You can set up the same sort of thing when you're running a build by hooking it up in buildAll.xml.
That said... wouldn't it be more useful to parameterize this setting somehow, so that users can define their debug setting from within the UI or via commandline flag? How much work would it be for you to write an extension in perhaps net4j.util to change this single attribute? You could load the doc as a dynamic EMF instance, parse the tree, change the attrib, and save it back to the same resource (whether inside a jar or not).
<priority value="info"/> => <priority value="debug"/>
Unfortunately, I won't be able to meet you in Germany next month. You'll have to either mail me those delicious drinks or wait until I get over there in the future. Failing that, we can have a virtual pub night sometime. ;-) When you're out with Ed, find me on Skype and I'll join you.

Ok, I've just realized that now I'm allowed to commit chages to my releng resources. Didn't know that before. Nevertheless I'd prefer to discuss my changes/issues with you and let you apply the changes because the existing structure of the build system seems too complex (-> fragile) for me. Maybe I'll understand better in the future.
Regarding this issue, I've tried several times to enhance the interwork of Eclipse and Log4j (make Log4j bundle-aware). Unfortunately that always ended in frustration because of the (IMHO) bad design of Log4j. GoF Singleton is present everywhere ;-( I know that other are working on this area (see http://wiki.ops4j.org/dokuwiki/doku.php?id=pax:logging) but I plan to replace Log4j by OSGi facilities in next releases. These facilities have heir own laws however, but I'll come up with a modular and configurable solution soon.
For the moment we have to stick with Log4j and the releng outcome should be the following: 1. log4j-priority is debug in CVS (DONE!) 2. log4j-priority is debug in SDK zip 3. log4j-priority is info in runtime zip 4. log4j-priority is debug when running tests
Please decide on your own where to insert/remove priority-replacement calls. This depends on how the build works (which item is derived from which item?).

(In reply to comment #4) > 3. log4j-priority is info in runtime zip > Please decide on your own where to insert/remove priority-replacement calls. > This depends on how the build works (which item is derived from which item?).
See, that's the problem - I'm not sure where to apply the tweak. This is a generated file that appears somewhere in a jar in your runtime zip, correct? Can you point me to where this file / these files are? Also, please note that your Update Manager site is generated from the SDK zip (at the moment) so users installing from UM will get the debug setting not the info setting. ... unless this change applies to the same plugin(s) in both SDK and runtime?

re: This is a generated file that appears somewhere in a jar in your runtime zip, correct? What is a generated file? The log4j.xml is not generated, but you know this, so which file do you mean?
re: Also, please note that your Update Manager site is generated from the SDK zip... Hmm, I find it hard enough to maintain several features (this one generates that one and so on). I really don't think that the actual location from where these feature zips are obtained (or how) should play a role for us. An SDK is an SDK and if someone chooses to use UM as a source for features, she should simply be aware of *what* she's gonna get from there. If it's the SDK then let it be and the installed feature should not differ from a manual download/install. Do you know what I mean?
Since 0.8 is a complete rewrite 0.7 will not be maintained.

bug.short_desc: grammar restriction : cannot replicate invOrDefCS

long_desc.thetext:
For parsing OCL documents the grammar have to provide the possibility to define multiple definition in the same context. Actually the generated parser cannot compile this phrase : package test context TestClass def: test1(t:String): String = 'coucou1'.concat(t) def:test2(t:String): String = 'coucou2'.concat(t) endpackage
grammar change : package -> 'package' pathName context+ 'endpackage' | context*
context -> classifierContext | operationContext | propertyContext
classifierContext -> context pathName invOrDef ...
* we would need this :
classifierContext -> context pathName invOrDef+
This is being fixed in the rework of the parser for EMF 2.3 (J2SE 5.0) adoption and support for the UML metamodel.
Committed the fix. The new org.eclipse.ocl.OCL class provides API for parsing OCL documents, and now supports multiple definition and/or invariant constraints in a classifier context.

bug.short_desc: 'self' context cannot be redefine

long_desc.thetext: This is being fixed in the rework of the parser for EMF 2.3 (J2SE 5.0) adoption and support for the UML metamodel.

Committed the fix. The org.eclipse.ocl.OCL class now provides an API for parsing OCL documents. The package context supports any number of classifier contexts, including repetition of the same classifier context.

bug.short_desc: Changes in task will not be reflected correctly in task descriptor

long_desc.thetext:
Build: epf-composer-1.0-M5-N20060907-1720-win32
Steps: 1. Open RMC with library OpenUP 2. Create a new plugin myplug, create a cp: mycp 3. Dnd a task in OpenUP into mycp,e.g. define_architecture 4. the primary role of define_architecture is architect, change it to another role, e.g.any_role 5. task define_architecture has 4 madantory input, remove one(vision), add one(use case). 6. Do synchronization on the task descriptor define_architecture in mycp
Unexpected result: TA has two roles: old(architect) and new one(any_role) WPU has old(vision) and new one(use case) But in property view of the task, the role and workproduct tab, show correct new ones.
Sorry, a mistake, step1 is open epf with library OpenUp
I can't reprodcue it. Please double check.

When you change primary role of the task define_architecture to any_role and then synchronize on the task descriptor, the role descriptor architect did not get deleted b/c it is still responsible for some existing work product descriptors (Architectural Proof-of-Concept, Architecture). The old unused work product descriptor vision will be removed if you synchronize the activity.
Basicall the rules for synchronization are following:
- Synchronize on descriptor will not remove any unused descriptor - Synchronize on activity will remove unused descriptors under it - A descriptor is considered unused if it is not associated with any other descriptor
sounds reasonable

bug.short_desc: Replacing a task will not be reflected correctly in task descriptor

long_desc.thetext:
Build: epf-composer-1.0-M5-N20060907-1720-win32
Steps: 1. Open epf with library OpenUP 2. Create a new plugin myplug, create a cp mycp 3. Dnd a task in OpenUP into mycp,e.g. define_architecture, the primary role is architect and it has 4 mandatory input 4. Create a new task in myplugin, primary role is project manager, and mandatory input is project plan 5. Let new task replace define_architecture 6. Do synchronization on task descriptor in mycp
Unexpected results: TA has two roles: old(architect) and new (project manager) WPU has old 4 input and new(project plan) But in property view of the task descriptor, role tab shows new one, workproduct tab shows new and old ones
please investigate and comment.

> Unexpected results: > TA has two roles: old(architect) and new (project manager) > WPU has old 4 input and new(project plan)
This is by design since role descriptor architect is still associated with other old inputs (responsible for). See 156666 for more details
> But in property view of the task descriptor, role tab shows new one, > workproduct tab shows new and old ones
This was caused by collecting associated work product descriptor using task design_architecture instead of its replacer. Fix committed.

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] regression in 3.2 - TreeViewer does not show colors with DecoratingLabelProvider with nested label provider implementing IColorProvider

long_desc.thetext:
We use a TreeViewer with has a DecoratingLabelProvider and a nested label provider which applies the color to the tree items. The used lightweight decorators only add some image decorations on a few items. Everythig worked well in Eclipse 3.1 but in Eclipse 3.2 the color from the label provider is only applied to the few decorated items. The others remain black.
This behaviour is caused by line 278 in TreeViewer.class:
if (!updateLabel.hasPendingDecorations()) getColorAndFontCollector().applyFontsAndColors(treeItem);
Because no decoration is applied to most of the items, the updateMethod is not called again for these and the color is never set.
The critical lines aboved seem to be included by bug #130340.
Looks like a regression in 3.2 introduced by the fix to bug 130340.

bug.short_desc: [Progress] IProgressService#busyCursorWhile() opens ProgressMonitorDialog with unmodifyable main taks name

long_desc.thetext: Please feel free to attach a patch should you have a solution in hand

Today I decided to investigate the source of this bug. And I think that I found it.
When we use PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getProgressService().busyCursorWhile(), this method creates ProgressMonitorJobsDialog (subclass of ProgressMonitorDialog) and sets its openOnRun property to false.
Finally the problem is placed in class ProgressMonitorDialog in method private void setMessage(String messageString).
There is this statement: if (messageLabel == null || messageLabel.isDisposed() || !messageLabel.isVisible()) { return; } which prevents setting task name when messageLabel widget is not created or visible.
ProgressMonitorJobsDialog by default is not opened and became visible before task execution begin, and task name is not set.
So, the resolution is to delete "!messageLabel.isVisible()" condition or to change it to (!messageLabel.isVisible() && openOnRun)
I'll try and look at this in 3.4

Is there a work around for this in Eclipse 3.2? I have the same issue.
thanks,
Barry
There is not currently a workaround for this.
This is working in 3.4. I will attach a plug-in to demonstrate.

bug.short_desc: Call Hierarchy does not handle polymorphic method calls

long_desc.thetext:
(In reply to comment #1) > What you demand is impossible, unless you can solve the Halting Problem for > this program:
If people actually write code like that, they deserve to have call hierarchy not work for them ;)
Anyway, if it's easy for us to resolve the concrete type of an object, we should try our best to resolve the reference (if it's possible to do statically, that is). Otherwise, we can fall back to referencing the virtual function in the base class. We'll have to do the latter in cases where the virtual call will go to different derived classes depending on what happened at runtime.

(In reply to comment #1) > What you demand is impossible, unless you can solve the Halting Problem for > this program: > #include "your_example.h" > Base* foo(); //a library function > void main() > { > while(!dynamic_cast<Derived*>(foo())); > } I am not discouraged, your example is quite easy, the call-hierarchy will show you that main() makes a function-call to foo(), it does not care about how often the call is actually made at runtime and whether your program terminates or not.

bug.short_desc: PDom: need to know if virtual mechanism is used for methodcall

long_desc.thetext: Method resolution is not currently considering virtual. There are a number of bugs on the topic of virtual methods. See also bug 86654, bug 93191, and bug 51483.

Andrew, for resolving the reference (from IASTName to IBinding) you do not have to consider virtual, do you? In the sample I'd expect to get a binding to Base::virtualMethod() in both cases. The Call Hierarchy itself will have to analyze type-hierarchies to figure out potential calls to derived methods. However, by looking into the PDOM it currently cannot figure out, whether or not the virtual call mechanism is explicitly suppressed by qualifying the method call. And I am asking for storing this as a property of the reference in the PDOM. Does that make sense to you?

Generally we don't need to consider virtual, but there are 2 special cases that I know of (using declarations & templates) that we do not handle correctly.
I see now though what you are saying, the information you want is not so much about the binding you got, but about the reference. I don't know how the PDOM works here, but we almost want a Reference to be an object itself in the PDOM rather than just a file/offset. Then extra information like this could be easily added.

The PDOM gets its info from the DOM. I resolve the binding for the names first and then map them to the PDOM. So I rely on the binding resolution mechanism to figure out which method in the inheritance heirarchy the name is a reference to.

(In reply to comment #4) > The PDOM gets its info from the DOM. I resolve the binding for the names first > and then map them to the PDOM. So I rely on the binding resolution mechanism to > figure out which method in the inheritance heirarchy the name is a reference > to.
Again, the binding itself is not the problem, I simply need additional information on how the reference was made (with using a qualifier or not). This information cannot be found in the binding but is part of the AST. So it can be determined and stored in the PDOM. If we fail to do so, the Call Hierarchy would have to generate AST for each reference it has to display, which is not a good idea.

So from a method call, you want to know whether you are guaranteed to call the referenced method, or whether it may end up calling a method in a subclass, i.e. where virtual is decided at the call site, not the declaration? Makes sense.
This kind of thing falls into the category of logical/semantic information. As such, it should be represented in the IBinding objects, and thus the PDOM. The AST is really only meant to represent the structural aspect of tokens. Obviously the DOM uses the AST to derive semantic information. It's a good question where we should store this info in the PDOM.

The information is stored in the index now. It can be accessed using IIndexName.couldBePolymorphicMethodCall(). I have created the testcase IndexNamesTests.testCouldBePolymorphicMethodCall_Bug156691().
Fixed in 5.0 > 20071212.
Hi - Any possibility this fix will make it into 4.0.3?

(In reply to comment #8) > Hi - Any possibility this fix will make it into 4.0.3?
It'd be possible. I need to use my time differently, though.
Markus, Any reason why we couldn't look into back porting it to 4.0.3? I can handle committing the changes.
I would not expect any problems in backporting the change.

bug.short_desc: [Call Hierarchy] show read/write access for variables.

long_desc.thetext: The call tree supports variables in addition to functions and methods. That is because a variable can be seen as a pair of functions (get/set). It is desirable to illustrate whether the reference to a variable corresponds to the setting and/or getting of the value. For that this information has to be stored in the PDom.
